newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Chinese vice premier Zhu Rongji arrives in Australia.
newsitem.headline: Chinese vice premier Zhu Rongji arrives in Australia.

text.p: Chinese vice-premier and economic tsar Zhu Rongji arrived in Australia on Friday for a landmark visit to cement improved ties and reward Canberra for an easing of its stand on human rights in China.

Australian officials said the week-long visit would focus on trade and investment and was the latest in a series of steps by Canberra and Beijing to repair relations damaged last year over a range of diplomatic and security spats.
Zhu is the most senior Chinese official to visit Australia since National People's Congress chairman Qiao Shi in 1994.

Zhu told Beijing-based Australian journalists this week that his trip, which replaces a cancelled European tour, was a payback for Australia abandoning a United Nations resolution censuring China over its human rights record.

Zhu said Premier Li Peng had asked him to travel to Australia as a reward for Canberra's decision not to co-sponsor the U.N. Human Rights Commission resolution this year, for the first time in seven years.
"You can see Australia this time really acted very good on the human rights question," Zhu quoted Li as telling him.
Announcing Australia's decision not to co-sponsor the U.N. resolution, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said last month the two countries had agreed to set up a formal human rights dialogue.
Australian officials said Canberra would push for an early start to that so-far unscheduled dialogue when Zhu is in Canberra early next week.
Downer said on Wednesday that he would also raise human rights concerns in his meeting with the Chinese economic leader.

Zhu's Australian tour replaces a planned visit to Austria, Ireland, Luxembourg and the Netherlands which Beijing-based Australian media quoted Zhu as saying was cancelled because of those countries' support for the U.N. motion.
Zhu arrived in Perth on Fiday night and is scheduled on Saturday to visit the Channar iron ore mine in the Western Australian outback -- a joint venture between China and mining giant RTZ Corp-CRA.
He also plans to visit an Australian winery in South Australia on Sunday before heading to Canberra for talks with Australian Prime Minister John Howard.
Zhu heads a delegation which includes leading business people and 10 officials of at least vice-ministerial rank.

Australian officials said Zhu, credited with China's rapid economic growth and a key force in the restructuring of state businesses, will discuss a range of economic and business issues, including a proposed A$500 million (US$390 million) reduced iron project in Western Australia state and wool quotas.
China is Australia's fifth largest trading partner, with two-way trade worth A$8.0 billion in calendar 1996.
Trade is growing about 20 percent a year and China is projected to move to Australia's number two trading partner, behind Japan, by 2005.
